MainHeading.P: Unfortunately, notwithstanding these inquiries, we have received no new information on Mr. Keenan's welfare or whereabouts. However, I can assure the Deputy that this matter will continue to receive my personal attention until Mr. Keenan is freed.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Underwater Naval Manoeuvres.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in view of the continuing threat to fishing vessels off the coast of Ireland from submarines of all nations, if his Department has taken steps to ensure that underwater naval manoeuvres are not carried out within Ireland's fishery limits.

asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs the action he is taking to prevent damage to trawlers and their equipment by the activities of submerged submarines in the Irish Sea; and if he will raise the matter through the Maritime Safety Organisation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Lenihan) Brian (Snr.) Lenihan
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 23 and 57 together.
Ireland's fishery limits extend to a 200 mile zone around the coast, an area governed by the Common Fisheries Policy.

Ireland's national control over foreign vessels however ends at the 12 mile limit of our territorial waters. Within these limits foreign vessels are entitled to exercise the rights of innocent passage. All submarines must identify themselves and travel on the surface when exercising these rights.

Beyond our territorial waters are international waters to which all nations have free access under international law. It would not be realistic to expect that nations would voluntarily surrender their rights in international waters.

MainHeading.P: However, the Government has taken action in relation to the safety of Irish vessels at sea, and particularly in the seas surrounding Ireland, which has been a matter of particular concern. An initiative which we sponsored at the International Maritime Organization (IMO) aimed at focusing attention on the problems posed to fishermen by submarine traffic, resulted in the unanimous adoption by the General Assembly of the IMO of a resolution entitled Avoidance by Submerged Submarines Of Fishing Vessels and Their Fishing Gear. It is our hope that this Resolution will make a significant contribution to the avoidance of incidents involving surface vessels and submerged submarines at sea.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Departmental Expenses on Properties.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will outline the policy decisions behind the massive increase of almost 500 per cent in the expenses on official premises in the Estimates for his Department for 1989.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Lenihan) Brian (Snr.) Lenihan
Speaker.P: In order to avoid duplication and increase efficiency, the Government have in recent years had under review the services being provided by the Office of Public Works for other Government Departments. As a result of this review, a number of services have been transferred from OPW to the relevant Departments.

In the case of the Department of Foreign Affairs responsibility for maintenance work and for premises overseas has been transferred to that Department from the Office of Public Works with effect from 1 January 1989.

As a consequence the amount provided in the 1989 Estimates for my Department in respect of expenses on official premises includes £3,320,000 transferred from the Vote for Public Works and Buildings in respect of contract maintenance at home and abroad and rents on overseas properties. Rents on my Department's accommodation within the State will continue to be the responsibility of the Office of Public Works.

MainHeading.P: There has been no increase in the amount of public funds to be provided in 1989 in respect of expenses on properties used by my Department. Indeed the overall amount provided for in the Estimates for 1989, taking the Vote for Foreign Affairs and the Vote for Public Works and Buildings together, is £800,000 less than in 1988.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Bilateral Aid.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will outline the policy decisions arising from the cutback from £10 million in 1988 to £9 million in 1989 in the Estimates for bilateral aid under the Overseas Development Assistance Programme.

asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if it is his intention to eliminate completely the grant-in-aid for bilateral and other aid contributions for developing countries, in view of the cumulative reduction in the Government's contribution to that fund of almost £5 million or 40 per cent in the last two published Estimates; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will make a statement on the Government's view of the importance of Ireland's bilateral aid programme; and the plans, if any, the Government has for its future development.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Lenihan) Brian (Snr.) Lenihan
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 26, 28 and 42 together.

Government policy remains one of commitment to the maintenance and expansion of official development assistance as soon as economic circumstances permit. The funds available in 1989 will allow us to meet all our commitments both multilateral and bilateral.

MainHeading.P: There is no intention on the Government's part to eliminate the grant-in-aid fund for bilateral or other aid contributions for developing countries. The Government considers bilateral assistance an important and effective means of channelling aid to developing countries. The amount provided for bilateral aid this year is not only sufficient to meet all our commitments but in addition sufficient to maintain the basic framework for expansion when economic circumstances permit us to do so.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Higgins Mr. M. Higgins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if, in view of the projected figures for emigration for the next several years, he will consider the establishment of a Commission on Emigration.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Lenihan) Brian (Snr.) Lenihan
Speaker.P: This Government has already taken a series of actions in Britain, the US and elsewhere to improve the position of our emigrants. These have been outlined to the House on several occasions.
Here at home we are taking action on the economy to ensure that no Irish person is forced to travel overseas because of lack of opportunity.
I believe that the steps we have taken at home and abroad are addressing the main causes of emigration as well as the difficulties faced by our citizens overseas.
While I appreciate the spirit behind the Deputy's question there are no plans at the present time to appoint a commission similar to that established in 1948.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - International Human Rights Conference.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he has received an invitation to attend and participate in the proposed International Human Rights Conference to be held in the Soviet Union in the near future; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Lenihan) Brian (Snr.) Lenihan
Speaker.P: The conference referred to is the Conference on the Human Dimension, proposed by the Twelve at the Vienna CSCE follow-up meeting. The Soviet Union has proposed Moscow as one of the three conference venues. The question of the venues is still under negotiation in Vienna, and hence the question of an invitation does not arise at this stage. The proposal will be considered in the framework of the overall outcome of the Vienna meeting which deals with security questions and economic, scientific and technological co-operation as well as with human rights. Ireland, along with its partners in the Twelve, attaches great importance to fulfillment by the Soviet Union of its commitments under the Final Act.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Birmingham Six and Guildford Four Cases.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs the further action he intends to take to obtain the release of the Birmingham Six and the Guildford Four; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. O'Malley Mr. P. O'Malley
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will report the up-to-date position on the prospect of the Guildford Four case going to the Court of Appeal in Britain.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Lenihan) Brian (Snr.) Lenihan
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 37 and 39 together.

With regard to the Birmingham Six case, I indicated in a statement on 14 April this year that the Government consider that there are compelling humanitarian reasons for the Home Secretary to consider using the wide-ranging powers available to him in such cases. This remains our position. We have reiterated our concerns to the British authorities on all appropriate occasions, including when I met the Home Secretary on 14 September last, and will continue to do so.

As the Deputy is aware, the Guildford Four case is at present under review by the Home Secretary who is expected to decide in the near future whether to refer the case to the Court of Appeal. The Government strongly support a referral on a basis which will allow the court to examine fully all the relevant evidence. The Home Secretary is fully aware of our position on the matter.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Prevention of Terrorism Act Detentions.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs the number of Irish people detained under the Prevention of Terrorism Act in Britain in each of the past three years; the numbers, if any, subsequently charged with specific offences; and if he has satisfied himself that the Act is not discriminatory to Irish nationals.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Lenihan) Brian (Snr.) Lenihan
Speaker.P: The number of people detained for one hour or more under the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA), in connection with the situation in Northern Ireland, and the number subsequently charged is as follows:

asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will make a statement on the Government's policy in relation to development education.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Lenihan) Brian (Snr.) Lenihan
Speaker.P: Development education is a very important element in our development co-operation programme. Development education activities in the formal education sector and among the development non-governmental organisations (NGOS) and other agencies will continue to be encouraged and supported by my Department.

In order to provide professional advice and assistance to organisations involved in development education and to facilitate the introduction of development education activities into the formal education sector my Department have financed the establishment of the development education support centre (DESC). It is based at St. Patrick's College in Dublin with a regional office in Limerick. My Department have also supported a resource centre at University College Dublin. The allocation of grants for the provision of development education in the formal education system is carried out by a broadly based committee with administrative support provided by Higher Education for Development Co-operation (HEDCO). Grants to Development NGOS and other organisations are administered directly by my Department. Among the organisations assisted have been the World Education Project in Sligo, Comhlamh, the Irish Congress of Trade Unions (ICTU), Trocaire and the National Federation of Youth Clubs. Funding has also been provided for the RTE radio programme “Worlds Apart” and other mass media activities. Information material on Irish official development assistance including an annual report is published by my Department.
In 1987 the sum of £632,850 was spent in this area and £450,000 is expected to be spent this year.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Wildlife Statistics.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance in the event of any particular species of bird, animal, fish or insect being threatened with extinction, the method which is availed of and the system which is used by his Department to ensure the conservation of any such species.

asked the Minister for Finance the system used by officers of the Wildlife Section of his Department for the obtaining and keeping of records on the numbers of birds, animals, fish and insects in Ireland.

asked the Minister for Finance the numbers of wild duck, woodcock, snipe, wild geese, pheasants, mallard, partridge, wood pigeon, wigeon and teal in Ireland; if he will give statistics for same in each five-year period commencing in 1960 up to the present date; and if he has satisfied himself that there is no threat of extinction to any of these species in Ireland.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. MacSharry) Ray MacSharry
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 73, 74 and 75 together.
The systematic collection of data on the numbers of all species of fauna found in Ireland has not been undertaken. However data on some species is available.

MainHeading.P: In relation to the population sizes of individual species, the critical factors are the general status nationally of any population and the degree to which any existing threats may adversely affect that status. Precise censusing for all species is not therefore generally undertaken. However, for species which are regarded as threatened or in danger of extinction or for which Ireland has a special responsibility, precise censusing and monitoring programmes are carried out, the nature of which will vary according to the species concerned. For example, Ireland's four species of geese, Brent, Barnacle, Greylag and Greenland WhiteFronted, are censused regularly by co-ordinated field surveys throughout their ranges. National population data are available for these species for some periods and I have arranged for this information to be forwarded to the Deputy in due course.

The conservation of any species is based on two main strategies, namely, the regulation of exploitation and the protection of habitats. Exploitation is regulated under the Wildlife Act, 1976 through the fixing of open seasons for shooting and regulation and monitoring of the trade in these species. The regulations are enforced by a corps of wildlife officers. There is a complete ban on the taking of some species. Protection of habitat is effected within the general policy objectives of the creation of a network of protected areas representative of all ecosystems found in the country.
No precise statistics are available for the remaining species listed by the Deputy but I am satisfied that there is no threat of extinction to any of these species.
The conservation of fish stocks is a matter for the Department of the Marine.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Food his views on the European Commission proposals on veterinary controls and rules in intraCommunity trade; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy) Michael O'Kennedy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy)
Speaker.P: In the context of the realisation of the Internal Market the Commission of the European Communities has proposed a general strategy for veterinary controls. The strategy is designed to achieve a uniformly high standard of health and hygiene in all member states before 1993 so as to reduce the risk attached to movement of animals and animal products. I fully support that approach and will be pressing for effective action to be taken in relation to the major diseases affecting livestock in the Community.

The strategy also contains a proposal to discontinue veterinary controls at the internal frontiers of the Community and to substitute a system of controls which would operate at the point of origin of the animals, or products, and which would permit subsequent spot checks. I have some misgivings about this proposal and I will aim to ensure that the measures adopted afford the necessary safeguards against the dissemination of disease.

She returned to this country in January 1988 and again claimed unemployment benefit at Kenmare office from 6 January 1988. Payment was made to her with effect from that date until 4 September. She is currently in receipt of maternity allowance at the weekly rate of £43.60.

MainHeading.P: It has been confirmed from the Dutch authorities that the person concerned had registered as unemployed in the Netherlands from 7 December 1987 to 2 January 1988 but no payment had been made to her in respect of that period. As she is now living in Ireland the Dutch authorities have been requested to pay the arrears of unemployment benefit due to her under the EC Regulations in respect of the period in question at her Irish address.

The Dutch authorities have been contacted several times regarding the delay in forwarding payment of the arrears but for some unexplained reason they have not yet done so. The matter is now being taken up with the Dutch social service liaison officer who deals with questions relating to the transfer of social security entitlements between the Netherlands and other member states of the community.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Internal Market Impact on Employment.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour, arising out of the reply to Parliamentary Question No. 7 of 27 October, 1988, the plans, if any, he has to have comprehensive studies carried out on the employment impact of the completion of the internal market on various sectors of the Irish labour market; if he proposes to have this work done within his Department and/or in conjunction with FÁS; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: The determinants of sectoral employment levels, particularly projected levels, are complex. The major determinants would include the demand, actual and potential, for the products of the sector, the related levels of output and the methods of production. Consequently, the first stage in any study of the employment impact of the completion of the internal market for a given sector is to examine the market for the sector's products and the resulting level of output. The undertaking of such sectoral studies is a matter for individual Ministers and their Department as part of their responsibility for sectoral development policies.

In my replies to the Deputy of 27 October 1988, I gave examples of sectoral studies now under way in the Department of Industry and Commerce. As the results of these studies become available, my Department and FÁS will consider their implications for our training and other activities.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Oireachtas Legislation.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the legislation or sections of legislation for which he is responsible which have been passed by the Houses of the Oireachtas and not yet brought into force; and the reason the legislation is not yet in force.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: The only pieces of legislation for which my Department is responsible which have been passed by the Houses of the Oireachtas and not yet brought into force are the Safety Health and Welfare (Offshore Installations) Act, 1987, and Part II of the Dangerous Substances Act, 1972.

MainHeading.P: The Safety, Health and Welfare (Offshore Installations) Act, 1987, requires the making of statutory regulations to bring it into force. Detailed regulations relating to various specific aspects of workers' safety are in preparation. The aim is to have them in force in time for next year's drilling season. The position of the workers on the offshore installations is safeguarded meanwhile by a condition in the offshore operator's licence requiring compliance with directions from the Department of Labour for securing the safety, health and welfare of the workers. The current directions are contained in the code of Safety Instructions for Offshore Petroleum Operations issued in 1983.

Part II of the Dangerous Substances Act has not been brought into force. This particular part deals with explosives. As explosives were already controlled under special legislation administered by the Minister for Justice, Part II was excluded from the Commencement Order for the Dangerous Substances Act.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Medical Practitioners Act Changes.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the reason for the delay by the Medical Council in changing the rules under the provisions of section 27 (2) (d) of the Medical Practitioners Act, 1978 which provides that the council may make rules for receiving and considering applications for full registration in the General Register of Medical Practitioners; if his attention has been drawn to the great anxiety borne by many doctors who are waiting for full registration; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: The Medical Council is an independent statutory body established under the provisions of section 6 of the Medical Practitioners Act, 1978. The council is statutorily obliged to establish and maintain the General Register of Medical Practitioners and to satisfy itself as to the adequacy of the qualifications and fitness to practise of persons applying for entry to the register. Section 27 of the Act specifies the categories of persons entitled to be registered on payment of the appropriate fee. There are four main categories of persons entitled to full registration including the category with which the Deputy is concerned, that is, persons who can satisfy the council as to the adequacy of their training in accordance with the provisions of section 27 (2) (d) of the Act.

I am aware of the problem to which the Deputy refers. However, as the Deputy has indicated in his question, the making of rules under section 27 (2) (d) is a matter for the council. I have no statutory role in the making of such rules. I understand from the Medical Council that this subsection is currently the subject of proceedings before the High Court and in these circumstances, it would not be appropriate for me to comment on the matter at this time.
